Biography:
I am a Research Assistant Professor at the New York University Electrical and Computer Engineering department. I am also a member of NYU Wireless. Prior to joining NYU, I was a lecturer and a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Michigan in Spring and Summer of 2017. I received my Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering at the University of Michigan in April 2017. My Ph.D. advisor was Prof. Sandeep Pradhan. I also received my M.Sc. in Applied Mathematics in 2016. My research interests are in the general areas of privacy and security, wireless communications, information theory, and learning theory.

For more information please find my CV.

I am on the academic job market seeking a tenure-track assistant professor position.

Research Interests:
My research interests are in the general areas of privacy and security (Project 2), wireless communications(Project 3 and Project 4), information theory (Project 1), and learning theory (Project 5).


  • Cybersecurity: This project which focuses on quantifying internet users' privacy risks is in collaboration with NYU Wireless and NYU CCS. The project has led to several recent publications ([C2,6,9,11-13, J7] in CV). I am also the Co-PI of the NSF grant #CCF-1815821 titled `An Information Theoretic Framework for Web Privacy' which is related to this project.


  • Wireless Communications: This project focuses on wireless communications, and consists of two subprojects, i) energy efficient communication over millimeter wave networks ([C3,4, J6] in CV), and b) resource allocation in cellular systems ([C1,5,7, J3] in CV).


  • Multiterminal Information Theory: This project is part of my Ph.D. work where we study the fundamental limits of communication over networks. We consider distributed data storage as well as data transmission over interference and broadcast channels ([C8,10,14-25, J1,2,4,5] in CV).



  • Feature Selection and Function approximation: This is a recent project where we build upon the machinery developed in my Ph.D. work ([C10,14,15,23,25,J1] in CV) to construct practical feature selection and function approximation algorithms and derive the fundamental limits of feature selection in terms of classification accuracy.
